name: Michael D. Bailey
content: Michael Bailey Michael Donald Bailey Professor School of Cybersecurity and Privacy (SCP) College of Computing Georgia Institute of Technology About Me I am a profesor in the School of Cybersecurity and Privacy (SCP) at the Georgia Institute of Technology. Until recently I was part of a large cohort of faculty, staff, and students at UIUC that do great work in security called the Security and Privacy Research Group at Illinois (SPR@I). If you are interested in what I have done professionally, you are welcome to read my CV. Teaching Spending Fall '25 in Metz, France at Georgia Tech-Europe. There I am teaching: Fall 2025, Special Topics - CS-8803-R Fall 2025, Computer Networks - CS-6250-R (with the truely amazing Cecilia Testart who is teaching in the Atlanta campus) Last semester I was honored to be teach with the really awesome Ryan Shandler: Spring 2025, CS 3237 Human Dimension of Cybersecurity In the past I have taught a variety of systems classes including Operating Systems, Networking, Distributed Systems, and Security. The most recent classes included: Spring 2022, ECE 422 Computer Security I, Course Website Fall 2021, ECE 391 Computer Systems Engineering, Course Website Collaborators Before coming to GaTech, I was blessed to have had an incredible cohort of UIUC Ph.D. students who have graduated and moved on to do some amazing things: Dr. Paul Murley, Argonne National Laboratory, Capital One Prof.Joshua Reynolds, New Mexico State University, Walmart Prof. Deepak Kumar, Univesity of California, San Diego Prof. Zane Ma, Oregon State University Seoung Kyun Kim, National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) I was super grateful to have had the chance to work with Dr. Joshua Mason while at UIUC. At Michigan, I had an opportunity to co-advise (as research faculty), several amazing students: Dr. Jakub Czyz, Quadmetrics, FICO, Blumira, CrowdStrike Dr. Jing Zhang, Composite Capital Management Dr. Yunjing Xu, Square, Smyte, Cruise, DiDi Research My interets lie in exploring the security, performance, and availability properties of computing systems. My work seeks to both inform the development of these systems to address immediate, important societal problems as well as to fundementially enhance our understanding of the sciences underlying computing subfields including computer systems organization, networks, and security and privacy.
